lines.text: The last time I asked her for those letters, she made very uncouth noises with her mouth.
Where were you yesterday?
Oh, Stew and I went for a long ride. Dexter, is there any finishing school we could send him to?
Yes - Sing Sing!
Einstein. Yeh, swell guy. Little eccentric, but a swell - doesn't wear, doesn't wear any garters. Neither do I, as a matter of fact.
Anne Schuyler's in the blue book; you're not even in the phone book. Think that one over... sucker!
Anne asked me, uh, to come and see you about the divorce.
She did?
She wants me to arrange the financial settlement.
Listen, Grayson, I got 106 bucks and 75 cents in the bank. Now Anne can have any part of that she wants, but she's got to hurry, because I'm spending it awful fast.
You don't seem to understand. Anne doesn't expect anything from you. We would like to know how much YOU would want to ...
Now wait a minute! Do I get from you that she wants to pay ME alimony?
Now, before you go unconscious, I want you to get this through your nut.
I beg your pardon?
Unconscious. You know, when you don't know anything - your natural state! There's some people, you can't buy their self-respect for a bucket of shekels! Now I happen to be one of those guys.
We just thought...
Don't think! Let me do the thinking. Now you go back to that Schuyler outfit and tell them that I didn't marry that dame for her dough and I don't want any of her dough now.
Yes.
I was too poor to buy her a wedding present when we married, so I'll give her a divorce for a wedding present!
You know what to do in a drawing room?
It isn't a question of knowing what to do... it's knowing how to get IN one that counts.
Yeah, I know those bluenoses. Their ancestors refused to come over on the Mayflower because they didn't want to rub elbows with the tourists... so they swam over!
Well, Gallagher!
Hi!
Ohhh, I'm glad to see you! Hello, Hank, how are you?
Oh, fine, but kind of thirsty...
Thirsty? Come right in, I'll get you a drink, huh?
[starts to close door]
Oh, say, uh, you remember Joe?
Sure.
Well, I sort of invited him in to bend an elbow with us.
'Sall right, 'sall right, 'sall right, bring him in.
Come on, Joe, it's all right.
All right!
Hello, Joe!
Hello, kid, how are you?
Glad to see you, kid.
[starts to close door]
Say, just a minute.
Yeah?
Johnson's outside. You don't mind if he comes in and dips the beak, do ya?
No, no, bring him in. More the merrier.

[to Johnson]
Hey, come on, come on.
Hi, Johnson!
Hello, Stew old pal, how are you?
Glad to see you.
I'm glad to see you.
Come on in, come on in.
[starts to close door]
Say, lookit, wait a minute. I've got two of the boys I brought along with me, they're cruising around with nothing to do... you don't mind if I bring them in?
You brought two of them?
Yes.
That's all right, bring 'em in...
Come on in.
...well, what's the difference?
[... and the other 20 people come in]

[to Anne]
I know what's wrong. I'm colorblind. That's what's wrong, I'm colorblind. I've been sitting here for a half-hour looking at you and I don't know yet whether your eyes are blue or violet.
You should throw me out. Because I begin to get goofy ideas and they concern you, Anne.
None of your ideas could be goofy, Stew, if they concern me.

Well, my name is Smith. That you seem to have been able to stand for the last month. I am white, male and over 21. I've never been in jail... that is, not often. And I prefer Scotch to bourbon, I hate carrots, I hate peas, I like bad coffee, and I hate garters. I make seventy-five bucks a week, and I got eight hundred and forty-seven bucks in the bank... and I don't know yet whether your eyes are blue or violet.
That's because you're too far away, Stew.
[Kiss]
No use you you hanging around here. Just buy a copy of the Tribune, read it over, then make a rewrite... you can use it for your last edition.
It'll never make the last edition. It'll take me four hours to translate your story into English.
Oh, is that so?
I'm afraid. Take your hat off, might make an impression.
[Baker takes off hat]
Impossible. Put it on again.
What country is this library in? Miss Schuyler, how about car fare back to the front door, huh?
I've met some rotters in my time; but, without a doubt you're the lowest excuse for a man I've had the misfortune to meet.
The gentleman from the Tribune.
There's no gentlemen at the Tribune.
I hope you'll never have a daughter who'll give you gastritis.
Is she beautiful? Oh boss, I think pictures don't do her justice. If I were that guy, Zigfield...
You're certainly going to be poison to that Junior Leaguer from now on.
Gosh, I hope not. I got to call on her this morning.
You what?
Sure! I must drop in and see the witch. Her wounds need soothing.
For heaven's sake, Stew, are you completely bats? What for? I thought that story was cold.
Sure the story was cold; but, I'm not. I'm sizzlin'. Look!
Oh, came the dawn, came the dawn.
And with it came love. Oh, Gallagher, you've got to meet her. She's "it"!
And that!
And those and them!
Well, I've see her pictures and I don't think she's so hot.
Oh Gallagher, she's queenly. She is queenly. And I know queens!
And, oh, has she got herself a nose. And I know noses, too. That little snozzle of hers.
There you go, talkin' like a woman.
Well?
Well, you're my pal, aren't you? And don't turn female on me.
Mrs. Schuyler is not at home.
I know. I know. I waited outside, until she went out. She's a nice lady, she's all right; but, we don't vibrate well together.
I won't even pretend you haven't done me a great favor. I wish there was something I could do for you?
Hello. Hello, Mrs. Schuyler. Come right in. Have a slug of tea.
It's going to be a very interesting experiment.
To make a gentleman out of a tramp?
Exactly.
Now, Anne, you'll remember how much it cost to get rid of that baseball player.
You don't seem to understand that this one's different. He has brains.
There's a swell girl. I want you to meet her.
Who me? She wouldn't want to meet me - I'm just an old load of hay.
Here's what we'll do. We'll have a party down at your house. One of those spaghetti party's, you know? Haven't had one in a long time. Have we, Gallagher?
Not since you broke into society.

Listen, you'll never be anything but just the reporter that married the Schuyler's millions. Stew Smith is dead and buried. From now on, you'll be just Anne Schuyler's husband. A rich wife's magnolia. If you can smoke that without gettin' sick - you're welcome to it.
Let me know when you're quittin'
I'm not quitting.
No?
[sings]
"For he's only a bird in a gilded cage, a beautiful sight to see." Tweet. Tweet.
[Walks away laughing]
Oh, go on and laugh you hyena!

Oh, its a good thing your father passed away before he saw insanity ravage the family. I can't imagine what made you do such a thing. A reporter! Of all things, a reporter! A barbarian who let's his socks come down.
When you move down to my place, I'll show it to you.
In your place?

Yeah. Oh, it's great. Of course, it doesn't compare with this Colosseum of yours, here. But, will serve, m'lady, will serve. The architecture is, eh, well, it has a little feeling of Missouri Gothic and the furniture sort of leans toward Oklahoma Renaissance with a tiny touch of Grand Rapids.
Say, you know, you're nice. You're all right. You'll make a good wife.
Thank you, sir.
Well, not for me.

[singing to Anne]
Oh, you can't carry a tune, you can't carry a tune, all you are good for is to sit and spoon, spoon...
Where is Mr. Smith?
Oh, you mean Anne Schulyer's husband?
Yes.
Oh, he's probably very tired. You see, he's had to meet all these people personally tonight... What is it you call him - the Cinderella Man.
Well, daughter of the slums, how'd you get out of the ghetto, huh?
Don't turn around now, but, there's a very beautiful girl up there that seems to be staring at us.
Staring at us?
My mistake, she's glaring.
She's glaring - it must be my wife.
We never look at Gallagher as a girl!
No, well, what do you look upon her as?
Well, down at the office, we always just look at - - Gallagher, that's all.
Well, you see, they all consider me just as one of the boys.
Right!

[Skeptically]
In deed. How interesting.
That was kind of a rotten thing to do, Anne. After all, Gallagher's my friend. The least you can do is be courteous to her.
I thought I was very charming, Stewart.
You did? That's a lot of hooey. I'll go and apologize.
Oh, a party! Great! Great! Jolly times and merry pranks! That's me! I'm a guy who loves parties.
Have a seat.
Well, I've got a seat; but, I have no place to put it.
Oh, pardon me, sir; but, I've heard that one before.
Well, well, well. My little pal Gallagher's a gal, heh.

[Anne is reading the newspaper]
What does it say about the reception last night?
blah, blah, blah attended the blah blah and wore the same blah blah things.
You know what I should do with you? I should sock you right in that - funny little nose.
Yes, and I'd love it.
Sure, you'd love it.
Have we got a play, Anne. Oh, have we got a play! Of course, most of it's Gallagher's. She did most of it. That brain of hers. It just snaps like that all of the time.
I'm not interested in the way her brain snaps.
The man's insane!

Sure, I'm insane. But, I got some good news for you. This magnolia is leaving your sweet smelling vanilla joint! This bird in a cage is gonna button his own pants from now on. And that's what's known as telling the Mother-in-Law!
Holy jumping swordfish!
If you had to make a fool of yourself, why didn't you tell it to her, instead of writing?
Because I couldn't get her on the phone.
Imbecile!
You should have known better than to write, Romeo. I found that out a long time ago.
I should say you had. At the rate you two are going, we'll have to leave the country to save our faces!
Splendid, Mother! Let's hop over to Monte Carlo. It's a great place to save a face!
It's like a giraffe marrying a monkey.
You sir will never be a good putterer.
